content: I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
This could be a really interesting problem, but it's lacks specifications information

This could be an interesting problem, but it's currently very under-defined.

On the topic of graphing, some considerations come to mind:
- How big (height x width) does the figure need to be? Does it vary between graphs, and how so?
- (related) When plotting the next character to the right, what is the change in x value? Similarly, when plotting the next character above, what is the change in y value?
- Is there a threshold value for considering gradients as "steep"? The puzzle might not work well if this is purely visual, as it leaves the plotting function wide open for interpretation.

On the topic of ASCII art:
- Are there any rules for which column to use when switching between line types? E.g., I see that a "\" character must be placed directly below a "|" character on the graph, while a "/" character must be placed to the left of (and below) the same "|" character. Is this a standardised rule?

On the mathematical functions, not all languages will have an eval-like function, which might make calculating difficult:
- Do you only expect players to graph (regular) polynomial functions? If so, what are the range of powers that you will provide? How about coefficients?
- Do you expect players to calculate gradients? Do you expect players to implement a numerical method to do so? What is the margin of tolerable error?
- Please provide some description of how mathematical expressions (in line 1) will look like in your input description. E.g., "The formula takes the form of [[cN]]{{x**}}[[N]] {{+}} [[cN-1]]{{x**}}[[(N-1)]] {{+}} ... {{+}} [[c1]]{{x}} {{+}} [[c0]], where [[c0]], [[c1]], ..., [[cN-1]], [[cN]] are in range <specify range>. If any of [[c0]], [[c1]], ... are 0, the corresponding term is not displayed."
Please help me for description and cases. I don't know how to present the problem.
What are you trying to do? And since your solution takes MUCH MORE than 5 minutes to solve, this should not be a CoC.
It isn't a CoC, but a classic puzzle.

And this is an explication:
The program reads a mathematical function as a string and a range of x values.

It evaluates the function for each x using eval() and stores the results in a list.

It computes the minimum and maximum y values to determine the drawing height.

It creates a 2D grid of spaces to represent the ASCII graph.

Each function value is mapped to a grid position and plotted.

The y-axis is inverted so higher values appear at the top.

For each pair of consecutive points, the code determines the slope.

It draws / for rising values, \ for falling values, and _ for local extrema.

Vertical | characters are added to visually connect steep changes.

Finally, the grid is printed line by line, trimming trailing spaces.
